   • kevin bruton d355 task 1 a1 based on market research i chose to lead the market the market research data indicates that these roles are harder to staff so leading the market by setting the compensation to the 75th percentile will help to ensure these positions are filled with highly qualified individuals more applicants will be attracted to this opportunity due to the oppoutunity for higher compensation increasing the chance for top talent to be processed and filling these critical roles the bravo centers goal is to revitalize and we are doing so by leading the market in pay above the market leading the market in compensation will not only attract top talent but also motivate current existing employees who are already within the company to do better and stay with the company ultimately this will promote higher retention rates and reduce employee turnover a2 i will support recruitment by offering higherthanaverage pay making the bravo center more attractive to it and marketing professionals who are in high demand filling the understaffed sections of the organization to retain these employees i will include regular pay reviews to keep compensation competitive career development opportunities and performance bonuses to encourage longterm commitment a3 for the total rewards mix the base pay is slightly above the average at 57 of the mix this will attract skilled workers as mentioned before it is essential fill key roles especially in it and marketing where these skills are needed the variable pay performance bonus is set at 27 of the mix to motivate employees to meet goals my goal is to ensure that the emplyees in these critical rokles are adequately compensated for their efforts and feel they are valued the benefits are set at 16 of the mix which includes health insurance retirement plans and paid time off this decision is influenced by the need to keep employees happy reduce turnover and attract people who value worklife balance and financial security b1 ive put a lot of thought into how to distribute the pay mix across different job categories considering the unique needs and responsibilities of each role for the executive coo role the pay mix consists of 70 base pay 20 variable pay and 10 benefits ive focused on balancing a solid base pay with substantial bonuses to motivate strong leadership and decisionmaking leaders are crucial to driving the organization forward so it's important to offer a competitive package that attracts top talent the benefits are designed to ensure overall job satisfaction and loyalty and make sure that they are compensated in a way that will be able to push the organization to meet and even exceed its target goals for the administrative roles the pay mix is allocated as 80 base pay 10 variable pay and 10 benefits the administrative and operations roles are essential to the flow of the organization these positions are the backbone of the center and require consistency and reliability so ive allocated a higher percentage to base pay this ensures they have a steady income while the variable pay encourages them to contribute to our overall goals the benefits help maintain job satisfaction and support retention i want the administration and operation staff to feel valued and one way of doing that is by making sure they are adequately compensarted for facilities management the pay mix includes 75 base pay 15 variable pay and 10 benefits facilities management keeps the center running i decided to mix with a somewhat large base pay with a sizeable amount of variable pay to encourage them to go above and beyond in maintaining the center's infrastructure it is essential to compensate them for the great work they put in and by including the variable pay there is incentive to go above and beyond this compensation will come with expectation of excellence and with proper communication of these goals i am sure our expectations will be met if not exceeded for these roles for the grounds manager and supervisor roles the pay mix consists of 85 base pay 5 variable pay and 10 benefits the grounds staff are essential for the upkeep and the sanitation of the center their jobs are repetitive and the ksa is low for these roles in other companies they can be seen as replaceable and they are likely to receive low compensation for their hard work and efforts at the bravo center we care about all of our employees while that is a fact that many can be trained and start in these roles with little to no experience having competent grounds staff is essential to the health and prosperity of the business during c0vid19 the world was plagued by a pandemic and and sanitation works and fast food workers and other workers who were looked down upon were seen as essential workers thoguh the pandemic is over the overall experience highlighted our need for workers in these roles and by compensating them adeuquately with a consistent pay we can ensure the health and safety of are our staff clients and perosnell ive emphasized a higher base pay these roles are less about performance incentives and more about ensuring we have a reliable team to maintain the exterior of the venue as well as the health and safety of all parties benefits are included to support their overall wellbeing and job satisfaction for the marketing roles the pay mix consists of 65 base pay 25 variable pay and 10 benefits for the it roles the pay mix is 70 base pay 20 variable pay and 10 benefits marketing and it roles are critical and often hard to fill these roles can be very strenuous and the rewards can be variable ive leaned towards a higher variable pay to make these positions more attractive to those with specialized skills a competitive base pay ensures were in line with market standards and the benefits package helps retain these valuable employees these are growing industries that have a high turnover rate and the best way to combat this is to make sure were adewuatly compensating our workers in these roles for the food concessions roles the pay mix consists of 90 base pay 5 variable pay and 5 benefits for the operations roles the pay mix is allocated as 8 and 10 base pay 10 variable pay and 10 benefits for food concessions and operations the focus is on ensuring a stable base pay to keep turnover low i chose to give a stable base pay for these roles these positions are essential to customer experience so offering a stable reliable income with atleast some incentives and benefits is key to maintaining a motivated team as the grounds staff their ksa is low however if we want consistency and quality work we need to make sure our workers are adequately compensated the bravo center total mix chart department number of personnel base pay variable pay executive coo 5 70 20 administrative 10 80 10 facilities management 5 75 15 grounds manager supervisor 1 manager 1 supervisor 18 contingent workers 85 5 marketing 3 65 25 it 5 70 20 food concessions 50 90 5 operations 20 80 10 according to market lead policies and pay mix policies the compensation for it and marketing personnel is set in the 75th percentile the bravo center will be compertitive in compensation giving an advantage in recruiting it and marketing personnel by offering abovemarket base pay to attract top talent in these highly competitive fields additionally performancebased incentives are implemented to motivate and reward great work the benefits package will be including health insurance and retirement plans to attract stabilizing features that will encourage longterm growth flexible work options such as remote work and flexible schedules cater to the preferences of it and marketing professionals making the bravo center an attractive choice in a competitive job market c when building the pay structure i will consider internal equity by ensuring that employees in similar roles across different departments receive comparable compensation such as aligning the pay of it professionals with marketing personnel who have similar expertise and impact on the organization additionally i will consider external market competitiveness by setting pay rates slightly above the market average for critical roles like it and marketing where specialized skills are in high demand these factors will ensure that the pay structure is both fair internally and competitive externally supporting the bravo center's overall compensation strategy d i will compensate the coo with with stock options and restricted stock units in addition ill include a performancebased bonus tied to key objectives which will keep them motivated in revitalizing the organization the combination of stock options and performance incentives will attract a driven leader who is focused on immediate and long term results e for the 18 contingent workers on the grounds crew i will apply the common law test to determine their status as independent contractors i will be using behavior control and financial control to determine whether or not the works will be classified as independent contractors the first factor is behavioral control this examines whether the bravo center directs how the workers perform their tasks if the workers are independent contractors the center will not control their methods or schedules but will focus solely on the end result this level of freedom in how the work is done suports the classification of these workers as independent contractors martocchio 2020 the second factor is financial control this assesses whether the bravo center controls the financial aspects of the workers jobs such as how they are paid or whether their expenses are reimbursed if the workers are responsible for their own equipent and expenses it indicates they have financial control over their work which aligns with the status of an independent contractor martocchio 2020 together we will be able to classify the workers as independent contractors reference martocchio j j 2017 strategic compensation a human resource management approach 9th ed pearson

halo effect or reverse halo effectthis occurs when an interviewer becomes biased because of one positive or negative trait a candidate possesses interview biasthis is when an interviewer makes assumptions about the candidate that may not be accurate these assumptions can be detrimental to an interview process contrast biasthis is a type of bias that occurs when comparing one candidate to others it can result in one person looking particularly strong in an area when in fact he or she looks strong compared to the other candidates gut feeling biasthis is when an interviewer relies on an intuitive feeling about a candidate generalization biasthis occurs when an interviewer assumes that how someone behaves in an interview is how he or she always behaves for example if a candidate is help keep everyone involved on track and ensure the chosen candidate starts work in a timely manner here are some tips to consider when working with the interview process make sure that everyone is trained on the interviewing process allowing someone who has poor interviewing skills to conduct the interview will likely not result in the best candidate in a worstcase scenario someone could ask an illegal question and once hired the candidate can sue the organization it has been calculated that plaintiffs win about half of hiring discrimination cases that go to trial sometimes because of interviewers asking illegal questions for example i see you speak spanish where did you study it is a seemingly harmless question that could be indirectly asking a candidate his or her ethnic background to avoid such issues it is important to train managers in the proper interviewing process listen to the candidate and try to develop a rapport with him or her understand how nervous the candidate must be and try to put him or her at ease be realistic about the job do not try to paint a rosy picture of all aspects of the job being honest up front helps candidates know exactly what they will be in for when they begin their job be aware of your own stereotypes and do not let them affect how you view a potential candidate watch your own body language during the interview and that tools can predict job performance measures have different types of validity that capture different qualities there are three major types of validity content validity construct validity and criterion validity content validitythis refers to how comprehensively the measure assesses the underlying construct that it claims to assess as an example look at a job interview for a position as a banker this measure would have low content validity if it assessed whether the candidate was comfortable talking to many different people but not whether they were comfortable with math because the candidate would not have been thoroughly evaluated on every facet of being a banker the measure did not cover the full breadth of what the job requires construct validitythis refers to whether the measure accurately assesses the underlying construct that it claims to assess this can be evaluated by examining correlations with other measures that purport to assess the same construct when you ask if a measure has good construct validity you are asking does this test the thing we are interested in testing an example of a measure with debatable construct validity is iq testing it is intended to measure intelligence but there is disagreement about whether it measures intelligence as it claims or merely one type of skill criterion validitythis examines how well the construct correlates with one's behavior in the real world across multiple situations and manifestations for instance does the measure adequately capture the construct eg work ethic as it presents in real life eg getting tests i read it selection methods a clinical selection approach is probably the most common selection method and it involves all who will be making the decision to hire a candidate the decision makers review the data and based on what they learn from the candidate and the information available to them decide who should be hired for a job because interviewers have a different perception about the strengths of a candidate this method leaves room for error one consideration is disparate treatment in which one's biases may result in not hiring candidates based on their age race or gender one way to handle this and limit the personal stereotypes and perceptions of the interviewers is to use a statistical method in hiring in the statistical method a selection model is developed that assigns scores and gives more weight to specific factors if necessary for example for some jobs the ability to work in a team might be more important while in others knowledge of a specific computer program is more important in this case a weight can be assigned to each of the job criteria listed for example if the job is a project manager the ability to work with the client might be more important than how someone dresses for the interview in the example shown dress is weighted 1 while being able to give bad news to a client is weighted 5 in the example the rating is multiplied by the weight to get the score for the particular job criteria this method allows for a fairer process and can limit disparate treatment although it may not limit disparate impact a statistical method may work like this you and the hiring team review the job analysis and job description and then determine the criteria for the job you assign weights for each area and score ranges for each aspect of the criteria rate candidates on each area as they interview and then score tests or examine work samples once each hiring manager has scored each candidate the hiring team can compare scores in each area and hopefully hire the best person in the best way with the statistical approach there is more objectivity than with the clinical approach statistical approaches include the compensatory model the multiple cutoff model and the multiple hurdle model in the compensatory model a similar method of scoring is used as the weighted model but permits a high score in an important area to make up for a lower score in another area in the example the ability to give bad news to a client might outweigh a test score these decisions would be made before the interviews happen a multiple cutoff model requires that a candidate has a minimum score level on all selection criteria continuing with the example the candidate may be required to have a score of at least 2 out of 5 on each criterion if this was the case the candidate scored low on bad news to a client meaning he or she would not get the job in the multiple cutoff model in the multiple hurdle model only candidates with high preset scores go to the next stages of the selection process for example the expectations might be to score a 4 on at least three of the items if this were the case this candidate might make it to the next level of the selection process since he or she scored at least a 4 on three criteria areas1 example selection model with five columns and 10 rows columnsjob criteria rating weight total comments and interview questions job criteria are dress and personality interview questions are as follows give an example of a time you showed leadership give an example of when you had to give bad news to a client tell us how you have worked well in a team score on cognitive ability test and work sample rating each of the job criteria and interview questions is assigned a numerical value for rating and weight the total is computed the final score is assigned based on the sum of the values in the total column this is an example of a selection model with scores and weights assigned to each criterion sample selection halo effect or reverse halo effectthis occurs when an interviewer becomes biased because of one positive or negative trait a candidate possesses interview biasthis is when an interviewer makes tools can predict job performance measures have different types of validity that capture different qualities there are three major types of validity content validity construct validity and criterion validity content validitythis refers to how comprehensively the measure assesses the underlying construct that it claims to assess as an example look at a job interview for a position as a banker this measure would have low content validity if it assessed whether the candidate was comfortable talking to many different people but not whether they were comfortable with math because the candidate would not have been thoroughly evaluated on every facet of being a banker the measure did not cover the full breadth of what the job requires construct validitythis refers to whether the measure accurately assesses the underlying construct that it claims to assess this can be evaluated by examining correlations with other measures that purport to assess the same construct when you ask if a measure has good construct validity you are asking does this test the thing we are interested in testing an example of a measure with debatable construct validity is iq testing it is intended to measure intelligence but there is disagreement about whether it measures intelligence as it claims or merely one type of skill criterion validitythis examines how well the construct correlates with one's behavior in the real world across multiple situations and manifestations for instance does the measure adequately capture the construct eg work ethic as it presents in real life eg getting tests i read it selection methods a clinical selection approach is probably the most common selection method and it involves all who will be making the decision to hire a candidate the decision makers review the data and based on what they learn from the candidate and the information available to them decide who should be hired for a job because interviewers have a different perception about the strengths of a candidate this method leaves room for error one consideration is disparate treatment in which one's biases may result in not hiring candidates based on their age race or gender one way to handle this and limit the personal stereotypes and perceptions of the interviewers is to use a statistical method in hiring in the statistical method a selection model is developed that assigns scores and gives more weight to specific factors if necessary for example for some jobs the ability to work in a team might be more important while in others knowledge of a specific computer program is more important in this case a weight can be assigned to each of the job criteria listed for example if the job is a project manager the ability to work with the client might be more important than how someone dresses for the interview in the example shown dress is weighted 1 while being able to give bad news to a client is weighted 5 in the example the rating is multiplied by the weight to get the score for the particular job criteria this method allows for a fairer process and can limit disparate treatment although it may not limit disparate impact a statistical method may work like this you and the hiring team review the job analysis and job description and then determine the criteria for the job you assign weights for each area and score ranges for each aspect of the criteria rate candidates on each area as they interview and then score tests or examine work samples once each hiring manager has scored each candidate the hiring team can compare scores in each area and hopefully hire the best person in the best way with the statistical approach there is more objectivity than with the clinical approach statistical approaches include the compensatory model the multiple cutoff model and the multiple hurdle model in the compensatory model a similar method of scoring is used as the weighted model but permits a high score in an important area to make up for a lower score in another area in the example the ability to give bad news to a client might outweigh a test score these decisions would be made before the interviews happen a multiple cutoff model requires that a candidate has a minimum score level on all selection criteria continuing with the example the candidate may be required to have a score of at least 2 out of 5 on each criterion if this was the case the candidate scored low on bad news to a client meaning he or she would not get the job in the multiple cutoff model in the multiple hurdle model only candidates with high preset scores go to the next stages of the selection process for example the expectations might be to score a 4 on at least three of the items if this were the case this candidate might make it to the next level of the selection process since he or she scored at least a 4 on three criteria areas1 example selection model with five columns and 10 rows columnsjob criteria rating weight total comments and interview how you have worked well in a team score on cognitive ability test and work sample rating each of the job criteria and interview questions is assigned a numerical value for rating and weight the total is computed the final score is assigned based on the sum of the values in the total column this is an example of a selection model with scores and weights assigned to each criterion sample selection interviewers asking illegal questions for example i see you speak spanish where did you study it is a seemingly harmless question that could be indirectly asking a candidate his or her ethnic and weakest characteristics of this candidate would you rehire this person if a candidate will be driving a company car or vehicle driving records may be checked for example this type of check would be necessary for field salespeople who are given a company car to regularly visit leads and clients at their places of business criminal background checks may also be used if the position will include interaction with the public if the position requires handling of money a credit check may be required although a written notice is required to be given to the candidate before the credit check is carried out in addition written permission must be provided to the credit agency and the applicants must receive a copy of the report all these types of tests can be used to determine whether someone of test is that many people know the right answer but may not be honest in their responses most companies have a code of ethics and conduct for on the job behavior and sometimes these standards are types of data found on social networking sites that either qualify or disqualify them based on how their conduct matches the company's standards this can be an effective method to see the kind of image the candidate portrays during his or her personal time however keep in mind that multiple states have adopted laws that forbid companies from taking adverse action against representatives based tools can predict job performance measures have different types of validity that capture different qualities there are three major types of validity content validity construct validity and criterion validity content validitythis refers to how comprehensively the measure assesses the underlying construct that it claims to assess as an example look at a job interview for a position as a banker this measure would have low content validity if it assessed whether the candidate was comfortable talking to many different people but not whether they were comfortable with math because the candidate would not have been thoroughly evaluated on every facet of being a banker the measure did not cover the full breadth of what the job requires construct validitythis refers to whether the measure accurately assesses the underlying construct that it claims to assess this can be evaluated by examining correlations with other measures that purport to assess the same construct when you ask if a measure has good construct validity you are asking does this test the thing we are interested in testing an example of a measure with debatable construct validity is iq testing it is intended to measure intelligence but there is disagreement about whether it measures intelligence as it claims or merely one type of skill criterion validitythis examines how well the construct correlates with one's behavior in the real world across multiple situations and manifestations for instance does the measure adequately capture the construct eg work ethic as it presents in real life eg getting assignments done on time coming in to work on time not leaving early etc4 essential reading question 8this is not a form we suggest that you use the browse mode and read all parts of the question tests i read it selection methods a clinical selection approach is probably the most common selection method and it involves all who will be making the decision to hire a candidate the decision makers review the data and based on what they learn from the candidate and the information available to them decide who should be hired for a job because interviewers have a different perception about the strengths of a candidate this method leaves room for error one consideration is disparate treatment in which one's biases may result in not hiring candidates based on their age race or gender one way to handle this and limit the personal stereotypes and perceptions of the interviewers is to use a statistical method in hiring in the statistical method a selection model is developed that assigns scores and gives more weight to specific factors if necessary for example for some jobs the ability to work in a team might be more important while in others knowledge of a specific computer program is more important in this case a weight can be assigned to each of the job criteria listed for example if the job is a project manager the ability to work with the client might be more important than how someone dresses for the interview in the example shown dress is weighted 1 while being able to give bad news to a client is weighted 5 in the example the rating is multiplied by the weight to get the score for the particular job criteria this method allows for a fairer process and can limit disparate treatment although it may not limit disparate impact a statistical method may work like this you and the hiring team review the job analysis and job description and then determine the criteria for the job you assign weights for each area and score ranges for each aspect of the criteria rate candidates on each area as they interview and then score tests or examine work samples once each hiring manager has scored each candidate the hiring team can compare scores in each area and hopefully hire the best person in the best way with the statistical approach there is more objectivity than with the clinical approach statistical approaches include the compensatory model the multiple cutoff model and the multiple hurdle model in the compensatory model a similar method of scoring is used as the weighted model but permits a high score in an important area to make up for a lower score in another area in the example the ability to give bad news to a client might outweigh a test score these decisions would be made before the interviews happen a multiple cutoff model requires that a candidate has a minimum score level on all selection criteria continuing with the example the candidate may be required to have a score of at least 2 out of 5 on each criterion if this was the case the candidate scored low on bad news to a client meaning he or she would not get the job in the multiple cutoff model in the multiple hurdle model only candidates with high preset scores go to the next stages of the selection process for example the expectations might be to score a 4 on at least three of the items if this were the case this candidate might make it to the next level of the selection process since he or she scored at least a 4 on three criteria areas1 example selection model with five columns and 10 rows columnsjob criteria rating weight total comments and interview questions job criteria are dress and personality interview questions are as follows give an example of a time you showed leadership give an example of when you had to give bad news to a client tell us how you have worked well in a team score on cognitive ability test and work sample rating each of the job criteria and interview questions is assigned a numerical value for rating and weight the total is computed the final score is assigned based on the sum of the values in the total column this is an example of a selection model with scores and weights assigned to each criterion sample selection open position criteria development means determining which sources of information will be used and how those sources will be scored during the interview there are six steps of the employee selection process 1 initial screening application and interview 2 employment testing 3 selection interview 4 background and reference checks 5 physical examination and 6 decision to hire with respect to selecting qualified employees validity refers to how useful the tool is to measure a person's attributes for a specific job opening reliability refers to the degree in which other selection techniques yield similar data over time unstructured interviews pose questions that match the specific applicant whereas structured interviews are a set of standardized questions based on the job analysis there are different types of interviews such as telephone interviews panel interviews and meal interviews there are situational interview questions and behavioral interview questions interviewers need to be cautious of unconscious biases such as the halo effect biases employment testing includes personality tests cognitive tests and job knowledge tests there are different selection approaches the clinical selection approach and statistical approaches such as the compensatory model the multiple cutoff model and the multiple hurdle model
